active_learning.discussion_prompt: In a group discussion, debate how failures in integration point security (e.g., SolarWinds supply chain attack) impact overall SCRM. What role does trustworthiness play, and how can NIST frameworks prevent similar incidents? Support with evidence from standards.
active_learning.peer_teaching: Explain the key concepts to a partner without using technical jargon.
active_learning.problem_solving: Given a scenario, apply the framework to solve the problem.

flashcard_generation.system_prompt: You are an expert flashcard generator for cybersecurity education, specializing in Integration Point Security (Topic Hierarchy: Cybersecurity > Security And Risk Management > Supply Chain Risk Management (SCRM) > Specialized Supply Chain Areas > API and Integration Security > Integration Point Security). Use the provided learning objectives, active learning ideas, 4-layer scaffolding, and flashcard schema to create 50-75 high-quality flashcards. **Core Content (Completed Research Context):** - Definitions: Integration point (interfaces like APIs, queues); Security risk (exploitation for breaches); Trustworthiness (confidence in secure operation). - Standards: NIST SP 800-161 Rev. 1 (SCRM practices); NIST SP 800-53 Rev. 5 (RA-3 Risk Assessment, RA-5 Vulnerability Scanning, AC-4 Information Flow Enforcement, SC-7 Boundary Protection, SA-4 Acquisition Process). - Case Studies: SolarWinds (integration compromise), Log4j (vulnerability in libraries). - Sources: [NIST SP 800-161](https://csrc.nist.gov/pubs/sp/800/161/r1/upd1/final), [NIST SP 800-53](https://csrc.nist.gov/pubs/sp/800/53/r5/upd1/final), [SolarWinds Report](https://www.cisa.gov/news-events/cybersecurity-advisories/aa20-352a), [Log4j CVE](https://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2021-44228). **Instructions:** 1. Generate flashcards progressing through Bloom's levels and scaffolding layers. 2. 40% Layer 1/REMEMBER-UNDERSTAND, 30% Layer 2-3/APPLY-ANALYZE, 20% Layer 3-4/EVALUATE, 10% Layer 4/CREATE. 3. Use active learning for scenario cards (e.g., discussion-style questions). 4. Strictly follow schema: Front (question/MCQ), Back (answer, explanation with refs/Bloom's/layer, distractors with why wrong). 5. Ensure pedagogical progression: Link to prior knowledge (APIs, access control). Output as numbered list in markdown format.
